chapter.title: Firewall
chapter.para:
The Firewall Appliance is identified by the
symbol. If the Firewall Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.

As its name implies, the Firewall Appliance provides traditional firewall functionality, blocking traffic based on rules. Rules are based on a combination of protocol, source and destination. Unlike traditional firewalls but like many other ⪚ Software Appliances, the Firewall can simply monitor (rather than block) traffic of interest and log events (see .)

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for the Firewall Appliance is presented as three tabs. The first two tabs, discussed in and , allow the administrator to configure the behavior of the firewall appliance. The last tab allows administrators to view firewall events (see ).

sect2.title: Block/Pass List
sect2.para: The Block/Pass List, shown in , is an ordered list of rules. Rules may select (match) a connection. If a given rule does select a connection, the connection is either blocked or passed (depending on the value of action).

As new connections are made, the Firewall Appliance evaluates its rules in order. The relative order of the rules can be determined by observing the # column as seen in . The Firewall Appliance attempts to match the connection to each rule based on the rule's criteria (more on that in a moment). If the connection matches, the action specified is taken. Should no rule match a given connection, the default action is taken (see ).

Rules match connections based on six (6) criteria. These criteria are as follows. Note that the term source means machine which initiated the connection and destination means machine receiving the connect requests.
Firewall Rule Matching Criteria
traffic type
The traffic type criteria selects the protocol to be matched. Valid values are TCP, UDP, or PING (as well as a few combinations thereof).
direction
The direction criteria defines the location of the source and destination relative to the protected network. Inbound means the sorce is outside the protected network, and the destination within. Outbound means the destination is outside the protected network, and the source within.
source address
This property selects the IP address of the connection source. Valid values are in IP Matcher format.
destination address
This property selects the IP address of the connection destination. Valid values are in IP Matcher format.
source port
This property selects the port of the connection source. Valid values are in Port Matcher format.
destination port
This property selects the port of the connection destination. Valid values are in Port Matcher format.

sect2.title: General Settings
sect2.para: The General Settings tab contains only a single property, as can be seen in .
